message_1: A rod of length 10 cm is initially at rest at a temperature of 20 degree Celsius. The ends of the rod are suddenly subjected to temperatures of 30 degree Celsius and 10 degree Celsius respectively. Assume that heat flows in one direction only and that the thermal diffusivity of the rod is 0.5 cm²/s. Determine the temperature distribution in the rod at time t = 0.1 seconds using the wave equation.
message_2:
The problem presented is a heat conduction problem, not a wave problem. The wave equation is not applicable in this case. Instead, we will use the heat equation to solve the problem.

The heat equation is given by:

∂T/∂t = α ∂²T/∂x²

where T is the temperature, t is the time, α is the thermal diffusivity, and x is the position along the rod.

To solve this problem, we will use the method of separation of variables. We assume a solution of the form:

T(x, t) = X(x)T(t)

Plugging this into the heat equation, we get:

X(x)∂T(t)/∂t = α T(t)∂²X(x)/∂x²

Dividing both sides by αXT, we get:

(1/αT) ∂T(t)/∂t = (1/X) ∂²X(x)/∂x²

Since the left side is only a function of time and the right side is only a function of position, both sides must be equal to a constant, say -λ²:

(1/αT) ∂T(t)/∂t = -λ²
(1/X) ∂²X(x)/∂x² = -λ²

Now we have two ordinary differential equations:

∂T(t)/∂t = -αλ²T(t)
∂²X(x)/∂x² = -λ²X(x)

The general solution for X(x) is:

X(x) = A cos(λx) + B sin(λx)

Applying the boundary conditions at x = 0 and x = 10:

X(0) = A cos(0) + B sin(0) = A = 30 - 20 = 10
X(10) = A cos(λ10) + B sin(λ10) = 20 - 10 = 10

The general solution for T(t) is:

T(t) = C exp(-αλ²t)

The temperature distribution in the rod is given by the product of X(x) and T(t):

T(x, t) = X(x)T(t) = (10 cos(λx) + B sin(λx)) C exp(-αλ²t)

To find the coefficients B, λ, and C, we need to apply the boundary conditions and the initial condition:

T(x, 0) = 10 cos(λx) + B sin(λx) = 20

We can use the Fourier series to represent the initial condition:

20 = 10 + ∑[B_n sin(λ_n x)]

where B_n and λ_n are the Fourier coefficients and eigenvalues.

To find B_n and λ_n, we can use the orthogonality property of sine functions:

B_n = (2/L) ∫[f(x) sin(λ_n x) dx] from 0 to L

where L is the length of the rod (10 cm).

In this case, f(x) = 20, so the integral becomes:

B_n = (2/10) ∫[20 sin(λ_n x) dx] from 0 to 10

Solving the integral, we get:

B_n = (20/λ_n)[1 - cos(λ_n 10)]

Now we can write the temperature distribution as:

T(x, t) = 10 + ∑[(20/λ_n)[1 - cos(λ_n 10)] sin(λ_n x) exp(-αλ_n²t)]

To find the temperature distribution at t = 0.1 seconds, we can plug in the values:

T(x, 0.1) = 10 + ∑[(20/λ_n)[1 - cos(λ_n 10)] sin(λ_n x) exp(-0.5λ_n²(0.1))]

This is an infinite series, so we can approximate the temperature distribution by taking the first few terms of the series. The more terms we take, the more accurate the approximation will be.
